oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cancer Treatment at the AMC Cancer Research Center and Hospital
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: American Medical Center (Denver, Colo.)
Jews
Hospitals
Treatment and prognosis
Patients
Cancer
Cancer treatment and research
Photographs
Colorado
Denver (Colo.)
Colfax Avenue (Denver, Colo.)
West Colfax (Denver, Colo.)
Spivak (Colo.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Handwritten on envelope: ''#463 AMC Cancer Research Center and Hospital''. On back of photograph: ''Cancer treatment AMC.''

A female patient receiving treatment for cancer at the American Medical Center (AMC) Cancer Research Center and Hospital in Denver Colorado. AMC was located on the grounds of the former Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver. In the 1950s, the institution reincorporated as the American Medical Center and became one of the first dedicated cancer institutions in the nation.
Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.

Handwritten on envelope: ''#485 Dr. C.W. Spivak''. On back of photograph: ''Dr. Charles Spivak''.

Portrait of Dr. Charles Spivak standing outside an unidentified building. Dr. Spivak was a founder of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. Dr. Spivak also served as executive secretary from 1904 until his death in 1929.
Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Female juvenile patients playing on the lawn at National Jewish Hospital for Consumptives
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: National Asthma Center (U.S.)
Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital (Denver, Colo.)

Denver (Colo.)

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America, Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 78.
On back of photograph: ''#1141 NJH Pediatric Patients, 1907''. On envelope: ''Early Historical NJH pictures of Patients and campus''. Written on front of photograph: ''Our Little Wards.''

Four girls in dresses sit on the lawn at National Jewish Hospital for Consumptives in Denver, Colorado. Three girls are playing with toys, while one is sewing. The National Jewish Hospital (NJH) worked to prevent tuberculosis by accepting children who seemed susceptible to the disease, while offering good nutrition and plenty of fresh air to keep them healthy. The hospital was founded in 1899.
Donated by the National Asthma Center.

A female patient receiving treatment for cancer at the American Medical Center (AMC) Cancer Research Center and Hospital. Three nurses are surrounding the patient. AMC was located on the grounds of the former Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver. In the 1950s, the institution reincorporated as the American Medical Center and became one of the first dedicated cancer institutions in the nation.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mile High Photo Company (Denver, Colo.)

Sanatorium (Colo.)
Spivak (Colo.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

Handwritten on envelope: ''#458 JCRS Bookbinding and Print Shop''. On back of photograph: ''#458 JCRS, This is part of the industrial rehabilitation department at the Sanatorium of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society in Denver. Patients are taught bookbinding and printing. They are started on two hours work a day. This is gradually increased after careful surveys of their physical condition, to six hours a day. Their reaction serves as a measure of their resistance and a valuable guide to the necessary duration of sanatorium treatment. Their work has the psychological effect of relieving mental depression and creating confidence in the future.''

Interior of the bookbinding and print shop room of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). A large group of men and women are working on various tasks throughout the room. This room was part of the industrial rehabilitation department at the JCRS. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.

A picnic for auxiliaries of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS) that was held in the yard of Mr. and Mrs. J.A. Sharoff during the 1950 conference in Denver, Colorado. Dr. William Kline stands second from right in the back row. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver. Dave Edman's Hobby Lobby Revue being performed for patients at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). This Revue was a stage presentation of a radio program which was popular at the time. Dr. Charles D. Spivak standing on the front steps of a building while smoking a cigarette. Dr. Spivak was a founder of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS) and served as Medical Director and Superintendent until his death in 1927. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Exterior of the First National Jewish Hospital Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: National Jewish Hospital (U.S.)
Jews
Hospitals
Sanatoriums
Tuberculosis
Photographs
Exterior views
Colorado
Denver (Colo.)
Colfax Avenue (Denver, Colo.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America, Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 76.
On back of photograph: "National Jewish Hospital, #1075, c. 1899-1902." On envelope: "#1075 NJH."

Exterior of the first building on the campus of National Jewish Hospital. This building was known as the Frances Jacobs Hospital and was founded in 1899. In 1907, the name of the hospital changed to the National Asthma Center. It later became the Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital, National Jewish Hospital/National Asthma Center (1978), and National Jewish Center for Immunology and Respiratory Medicine (1985).
Donated by the National Jewish Hospital.

Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 84.
On back of photograph: ''JC.R.S Hospital Poultry yard''. On envelope: ''#1091 JCRS postcards of campus c. 1922''.

Poultry farm at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). A flock of chickens are gathered in front of a building which has ''JCRS Poultry-Farm'' painted on the outside. The JCRS featured its own dairy and poultry farm located on its campus. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
Photograph was donated by Sarah Holcolm Florida.

Dr. Arnold Shamaskin who served as Medical Director and Superintendent of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside Denver.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Banquet for Auxiliaries and Board Members of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society and American Medical Center
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Chutkow, Sam
Chutkow, Sam,--Mrs.
Winocur, Esther--(Esther Ila)--1905-1988
Winocur, Charles--(Charles C.)--1905-1968
Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (U.S.)
American Medical Center (Denver, Colo.)
Jews
Hospitals
Charities
Sanatoriums
Dinners and dining
Cancer treatment and research
Photographs
Group portraits
Event photographs
Colorado
Denver (Colo.)
Colfax Avenue (Denver, Colo.)
West Colfax (Denver, Colo.)
Spivak (Colo.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

Handwritten on envelope: ''#478 JCRS Auxiliary''. On back of photograph: ''left to right Mr. Sam Chutkow, Mrs. Sam Chutkow, Mr. Charles Winocur, pres AMC, Mrs. Charles Winocur #478 JCRS Auxiliary and Board Members''.

A dinner banquet for auxiliaries of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS) and American Medical Center (AMC). Pictured are Mr. and Mrs. Sam Chutkow with Mr. and Mrs. Charles Winocur. AMC was located on the grounds of the former Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver. In the 1950s, the institution reincorporated as the American Medical Center and became one of the first dedicated cancer institutions in the nation.
Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.

Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Dr. Bronfin, Dr. Spivak, JCRS groundbreaking 1920s.'' Handwritten on back of duplicate photograph: ''#460, JCRS, Staff including Spivak posed in front of steam shovel, Dr. Bronson [sic] - 1st row, 2nd from left, 14 from right.''

The participants of the groundbreaking ceremony on the campus of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The participants stand by a steam shovel and two men and three women are on the shovel. Dr. Isadore Bronfin stands second from the left and Dr. Charles Spivak stands in the middle to the right of a man holding a shovel. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Handwritten on envelope: ''#388 Residents of Nat. Home for Jewish Children'' and ''Jewish Sheltering Home 1910-1950s''. On back of photograph: ''#389 NJHAC post 1945 Denver''.

Three unidentified girls in a kitchen. One of the girls appears to be washing dishes and the other two are standing in front of a table of brown paper bags. The girls were in the care of the National Jewish Home for Asthmatic Children in Denver, which later became part of the National Jewish Hospital.
Donated by the National Asthma Center.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Handwritten on envelope: ''#454 JCRS Kitchen''. On back of photograph: ''#454 JCRS Kitchen storeroom - c. 1918''.

The kitchen storeroom at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside Denver.
Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

Handwritten on envelope: ''#462 JCRS Patient Activities''. On back of photograph: ''#462 JCRS Portable ultra-violet lamps are used extensively at the Denver Sanatorium of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society in the treatment of its patients. Feet and legs are not immune to tubercle bacilli, but the germs cannot live in the penetrating light from this lamp. 10-21-41''

A female patient undergoing ultraviolet radiation at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS).This treatment was used to kill tubercle bacilli germs. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.
ph462

On envelope: "#1092 JCRS Patients and Nurses c. 1920" On back of photograph: "Frenburg waiter in our dining room, #1092."

A man identified as Frenburg poses in a waiter's uniform in front of a brick building. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside Denver.
Donated by Sarah Holcolm Florida
